clean_content:
Definition / general

* Undifferentiated carcinoma of the pancreas with no glandular differentiation and with prominent infiltration by histiocytes and osteoclast-like giant cells* May be found in association with a differentiated component of [pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasductal.html)

Essential features

* Undifferentiated carcinoma with atypical neoplastic cells and lacking gland formation* Presence of multinucleated giant cells resembling osteoclasts

Terminology

* Undifferentiated carcinoma with osteoclast-like giant cells (UCOGC, UCOCGC)* Old terminology, not in use: giant cell tumor of the pancreas, osteoclastoma

ICD coding

* ICD-O: [8035/3](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf?sequence=1#page=63) - carcinoma with osteoclast-like giant cells* ICD-10: [C25.9](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/C15-C26/C25-/C25.9) - malignant neoplasm of pancreas, unspecified

Epidemiology

* M:F = 0.9:1 ([Am J Surg Pathol 2016;40:1203](27508975), [J Pathol 2017;243:148](28722124))* Commonly presents in the sixth to seventh decades ([Am J Surg Pathol 2016;40:1203](27508975), [J Pathol 2017;243:148](28722124))* 1.4% of all pancreatic cancers ([Am J Surg Pathol 2016;40:1203](27508975))

Sites

* Head of the pancreas (60 - 75% of cases), body / tail (25 - 40%) ([Am J Surg Pathol 2016;40:1203](27508975), [J Pathol 2017;243:148](28722124))

Pathophysiology

* Unknown; a role may be played by hemorrhagic / chronic inflammatory foci with recruitment of tumor supporting macrophages within the pancreas or within a pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma ([Hum Pathol 2018;81:157](30031096))

Clinical features

* Presenting symptoms include jaundice (tumors in the pancreatic head), abdominal or back pain, weight loss and nausea ([Am J Surg Pathol 2016;40:1203](27508975), [J Pathol 2017;243:148](28722124))

Diagnosis

* CT scan and MRI are the preferred imaging modalities* Diagnosis is by biopsy or surgical resection (more difficult with cytology but may be possible) ([Cancer Cytopathol 2017;125:563](28371566))

Radiology description

* Usually mass lesions with delayed enhancement ([Am J Surg Pathol 2016;40:1203](27508975))

Radiology images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasosteoclasticpmc05.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6283196/figure/F1/)

Ultrasound

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasosteoclasticpmc06.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6283196/figure/F2/)
â€ƒ
[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasosteoclasticpmc07.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4292306/figure/F1/)

CT

Prognostic factors

* Presence of an associated conventional ductal adenocarcinoma component is associated with a poorer prognosis and is one of the most important prognostic moderators ([Am J Surg Pathol 2016;40:1203](27508975), [J Pathol 2017;243:148](28722124))* PDL1 expression by tumor cells is associated with poor prognosis ([Hum Pathol 2018;81:157](30031096))

Case reports

* 54 year old man with a huge (28 cm) mass for which radical resection was possible ([Int Cancer Conf J 2017;6:193](31149501))* 54 year old woman with a large cystic mass in the pancreas ([Int J Clin Exp Pathol 2015;8:11785](26617927))* 61 year old woman with long term survival after surgical resection and chemotherapy ([Case Rep Gastroenterol 2016;10:472](27721735))* 62 year old woman with metastatic disease showing durable response to immunotherapy (tumor with high tumor mutational burden) ([J Natl Compr Canc Netw 2021;19:247](33668025))* 65 year old man with weight loss ([Medicine (Baltimore) 2018;97:e13516](30508980))* 68 year old woman with a prominent invasion of pancreatic ductal tree ([JOP 2011;12:170](21386647))

Treatment

* Surgical resection if possible, gemcitabine based chemotherapy ([Case Rep Gastroenterol 2016;10:472](27721735))* Immunotherapy is a novel opportunity to be explored in this type of cancer ([BMC Gastroenterol 2020;20:220](32652936), [J Natl Compr Canc Netw 2021;19:247](33668025))

Gross description

* Larger than conventional [ductal adenocarcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasductal.html) ([J Pathol 2017;243:148](28722124))* Brownish (not whitish) and with pushing borders* Frequent cyst formation* Hemorrhage or necrosis is typically present

Gross images

Contributed by Claudio Luchini, M.D., Ph.D.  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini01new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini01new.jpg)

Cystic tumor

  
  
Images hosted on other servers:  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasosteoclasticpmc01.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3204565/figure/F3/)

Hemorrhagic mass

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasosteoclasticgross1.jpg)](https://journals.lww.com/cancerjournal/_layouts/15/oaks.journals/ImageView.aspx?k=cancerjournal:2015:11040:00187&i=F2-187&year=2015&issue=11040&article=00187&type=Fulltext)

Macrophotograph revealing cystic mass

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasosteoclasticpmc08.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3186749/figure/F2/)

Cystic mass with gastric invasion

Frozen section description

* Hypercellular neoplasm with atypical cells* Multinucleated giant cells, although they cannot always be documented in small biopsy sent for frozen section (may be focal component)

Frozen section images

Contributed by Claudio Luchini, M.D., Ph.D.  

[![Osteoclast-like giant cells and neoplastic cells](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini02new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini02new.jpg)

Osteoclast-like giant cells and neoplastic cells

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Composed of 3 cell types:
  + Mononuclear neoplastic cells, sometimes very atypical+ Mononuclear histiocytes (nonneoplastic)+ Multinucleated giant cells (osteoclast-like giant cells) (nonneoplastic)* Foci of hemorrhage and necrosis are very common* Typical involvement of the pancreatic ductal tree, sometimes with a pseudopolypoid growth pattern ([J Pathol 2017;243:148](28722124))* May arise in association with [mucinous cystic neoplasm of the pancreas](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasmcn.html) and [intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm of the pancreas](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasipmn.html) ([Am J Surg Pathol 2016;40:1203](27508975), [World J Surg Oncol 2011;9:100](21902830), [Am J Surg Pathol 2015;39:179](25517958))* Osteoid material may be found ([J Pathol 2017;243:148](28722124))

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Claudio Luchini, M.D., Ph.D.

â€ƒ
[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini04new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini04new.jpg)

Associated conventional adenocarcinoma

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini05new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini05new.jpg)

Ductal tree involvement

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini06new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini06new.jpg)

Microhemorrhagic foci

  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini07new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini07new.jpg)

Extensive necrotic hemorrhage

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini08new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini08new.jpg)

CK8/18+

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini09new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini09new.jpg)

Focal CK8/18+

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini10new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasosteoclasticluchini10new.jpg)

CK8/18-

Cytology description

* 3 cell types (osteoclast-like giant cells, neoplastic cells and histiocytes) are present in most cases (~80%)* Cytology has a diagnostic value for this tumor in ~80% of cases ([Cancer Cytopathol 2017;125:563](28371566))

Cytology images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasosteoclasticpmc02.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2999083/figure/F1/)

Romanowsky stain

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasosteoclasticpmc09.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2999083/figure/F2/)

Papanicolaou stain

Positive stains

* Neoplastic cells:
  + [Cytokeratin AE1 / AE3](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsae1ae3.html), [CK7](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck7.html), [CK8/18](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/CK818.html) are usually positive but may be totally negative+ [p53](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp53.html) in > 50% of cases+ [Ki67](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainski67.html) high proliferation index* Histiocytes:
    + [CD68](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd68.html), [CD163](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd163.html) ([Hum Pathol 2018;81:157](30031096))* Multinucleated giant cells:
      + [CD68](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd68.html), [cathepsin K](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainscathepsink.html) ([Hum Pathol 2019;85:168](30447297))

Negative stains

* Neoplastic cells:
  + [CD68](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd68.html), [CD163](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd163.html), [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html), [CD45](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd45.html)* Histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells:
    + [Cytokeratins](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsckgeneral.html), [p53](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp53.html)

Electron microscopy description

* Neoplastic cells: abundant mitochondria, no microvilli or desmosomes ([J Korean Med Sci 2005;20:516](15953882))* Multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells: multiple nuclei with rim of chromatin; abundant mitochondria; free ribosomes; dilated, empty, rough endoplasmic reticulum cisternae ([J Korean Med Sci 2005;20:516](15953882))

Electron microscopy images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasosteoclasticpmc03.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2782216/figure/F4/)

Neoplastic cell

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasosteoclasticpmc04.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2782216/figure/F5/)

Giant cell

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* Overlaps with the genetic profile of conventional [ductal adenocarcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasductal.html), with the most common mutated genes being *KRAS, TP53, CDKN2A* and *SMAD4* ([J Pathol 2017;243:148](28722124))* *GLI3*, a gene belonging to the hedgehog signaling pathway, may be found mutated in this tumor* The same mutation (290â€‰Mâ€‰>â€‰L) affecting the gene *SERPINA3* has been documented in 25% of cases in a whole exome sequencing analysis ([J Pathol 2017;243:148](28722124))

Sample pathology report

* Pancreas, pancreatectomy:
  + Pancreatic undifferentiated carcinoma with osteoclast-like giant cells (see synoptic report)

Differential diagnosis

* [Undifferentiated / anaplastic carcinoma of the pancreas](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasundifferentiated.html):
  + Absence of osteoclast-like giant cells* [Paraduodenal (groove) pancreatitis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreaschronic.html):
    + Multinucleated giant cells may be abundant but neoplastic cells are lacking ([Cytopathology 2015;26:122](24650015))* [Melanoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skintumormelanocyticmelanoma.html):
      + Contains melanin pigment instead of or in addition to hemosiderin+ [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html)+

Additional references

* [WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board: Digestive System Tumours, 5th Edition, 2019](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/9283244990/pathologyoutl-20)
